content: Participate in the Voice of Democracy Scholarship Competition and the Patriot's Pen Essay Contest, garnering more than $3.4 million in scholarships and incentives.

title: Wings Over America Scholarship Foundation
content: Provides college scholarships to dependent children and spouses of all Navy - officer and enlisted - Active Duty, retired or deceased who served within Naval Air Forces.

title: Armed Forces Crossroads Scholarships for Military Children
content:
Find information on the Scholarship for Military Children
program, as well as additional scholarship resources and military and minority scholarships.

title: Heroes' Legacy Scholarships
content: Offers scholarships to children of Service Members who have died or have become disabled through their active military service since September 11, 2001. Program is funded through after tax proceeds from President Barak Obama's book, Of Thee I Sing. A Letter to My Daughters.

title: GI Bill Transferability
content: Find information on transferring unused Post-9/11 GI Bill educational benefits to spouses and/or dependents.

title: America's Promise Alliance (APA)
content: Operates educational opportunities for children and youth.

title: Career Exploration Program
content: Provides the DoD virtual, career exploration program that uses tools, tests and resources to assist high school and college students with exploring military and civilian occupations.

title: Military Families - Children's Education
content: Provides a wealth of resources on educating children including how to make successful transitions to new schools, aid for civilian schools, in-state tuition for Service Members and families, Department of Defense Schools, education resources for children with special needs, scholarships and more.

title: DoD STARBASE
content: Provides students with 20-25 hours of experiences at military bases across the nation in aviation, science, technology, engineering, math, and space exploration.

title: Education & Training for Young Marines
content: Provides youth education and service programs for boys and girls ages 8 through completion of high school to promote mental, moral and physical development.

title: DoD Tutoring Services
content: Access unlimited, free, online tutoring and educational mentorship provided to Service Members and their families through a partnership of DoD and Tutor.com.

title: Military Child Education Coalition (MCEC)
content: Provides information on various MCEC programs for children of military families, and resources to help parents address educational challenges that military children face. Includes information on scholarships.

title: SOAR (Student Online Achievement Resources)
content: Offers tools that can identify academic strengths and weaknesses in math and reading for students in grade 3 through high school.

title: Department of Defense Education Activity (DODEA)
content: Visit the homepage for the DoD's education program. Learn about education options for active duty children both stateside and abroad.

title: Military K-12 Partners
content: Provides military families with the tools and information needed to make informed choices regarding the appropriate school districts and educational settings for their children.

title: Military Parents' Guide
content: Provides resources for military parents, including tips on how to assist children during a school transfer or move, and tools to locate area schools.

title: AASA Toolkit - Supporting the Military Child
content: Access fact sheets, answers to questions, videos and links to other helpful resources to meet the educational needs of children whose parents are deployed or in transition.

title: Department of Education - Financial Aid
content: Learn about different options for paying for college, including federal loans, grants, and work-study. Includes frequently asked questions and information on how to apply for federal financial aid for college.

title: Family Federal Education Loan (FFEL) Program
content: Provides information on federal education loans available to all qualifying Americans, including links on applications, eligibility, awards, and laws.

title: VA Survivors' & Dependents' Educational Assistance
content: Fact sheet on education benefits for eligible spouses and children of certain veterans.  Eligible family members can receive up to 45 months of full-time or equivalent benefits to advance their education.

title: No Greater Sacrifice
content: Find information about scholarships for the children of fallen and wounded Service Members.

title: Adrian & Corena Swanier Scholarship for Military Children
content: Awards five $1,000 scholarships to military children for use towards four-year degrees, or vocational or technical certificates.

title: Army Scholarship Foundation
content: Provides college scholarships to the sons and daughters of those who served in the United States Army and to spouses of enlisted soldiers serving on active duty in the United States Army.

title: DRS Scholarship Fund for Children of the Fallen
content: Provides $6,250 a year for children of fallen National Guardsmen who are attending college.

title: DoD Online Student Pre-Registration System
content: Pre-register children in a DoD school from anywhere in the world and even while on the move from one installation to another using this new online pre-registration tool.

title: Operation Homefront - Military Child of the Year
content: Awarded in April of each year to outstanding military children who demonstrate resiliency, leadership and achievement. Prizes include a laptop computer and cash.

title: American Freedom Foundation/Kaplan University Scholarship Program
content: Provides support to certain children and spouses of U.S. Service Members that want to attend an online undergraduate degree program at Kaplan University. Includes information on program guidelines and two different applications for students based on grade point average.

title: Military Impacted Schools Association (MISA)
content: A national organization of school superintendents serving school districts with a high concentration of military children. MISA conducts workshops for educators and provides resources on connectedness, building resilience, military life, transition and deployment.

title: National Guard Youth Foundation
content: Provides scholarships, training and workforce transition assistance to the graduates of the National Guard Youth ChalleNGe Program and fosters program awareness to promote the success of the program. The ChalleNGe Program provides opportunities to adolescents who have dropped out of school but demonstrate a desire to improve their potential for successful and productive lives.

title: Air Force Special Needs Identification Assignments Coordination (SNIAC) Program
content: Provides special assignment consideration to Air Force members who have a spouse, child or dependent adult with medical conditions requiring prolonged hospitalization or out-patient treatment.

title: Benefits for Children with Disabilities
content: Describes the kinds of Social Security, Supplemental Security Income (SSI) and health benefits a child with a disability might be eligible for and explains the evaluation of disability claims for children.

title: Categories of Disability under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA)
content: There are 14 primary disabilities included in the IDEA under the definition of child with a disability. These definitions guide how states define disability, and determine eligibility for a free public education under special education laws.

title: Department of Education Office of Special Education & Rehabilitative Services (OSERS)
content: Dedicated to improving results for infants, toddlers, children and youth with disabilities ages birth through 21 by providing leadership and financial support to assist states and local districts.

title: Parents' Dependency & Indemnity Compensation (DIC)
content: Provides a basic monthly payment for an eligible surviving spouse. The monthly payment is increased for each dependent child, and also if the surviving spouse is housebound or in need of aid and attendance. VA also adds a transitional benefit to the surviving spouse's monthly DIC if there are children under age 18. The amount is based on a family unit, not individual children. Surviving parents are also eligible for this program.

title: Children of Women Vietnam Veterans Health Care Program
content: Covers most healthcare services and supplies that are medically or psychologically necessary for the treatment of conditions related to the covered birth defect of children of women Vietnam Veterans.

title: Spina Bifida Health Care Program
content: Covers most healthcare services and supplies that are medically or psychologically necessary for the treatment of conditions related to spina bifida. The VA can also reimburse expenses for travel to and from the doctor or health care facility.Some services require specific advance approval or preauthorization.

title: Payments for Children with Spina Bifida whose Parents Served in Vietnam or Korea
content: Learn about how people with spina bifida who are natural children of Vietnam and Korea Veterans may be eligible for a monthly monetary allowance.

title: Vocational Training for Children with Spina Bifida or Other Birth Defects
content: Enables a qualified child to prepare for and attain suitable employment. Services may include mentoring, counseling and rehabilitative services, education, training, and employment services leading to suitable employment. VA pays for the cost of these services.

title: Autism Society of America (ASA)
content: Increases public awareness and advocates for individuals with autism.

title: Autism Speaks
content: Promotes and advocates for best practices in treatment, education and all services - from early intervention to adult care.  Family services include Tools for Families, links to local resources, information on opportunities to participate in research and contacts for specially trained Autism Response Team (ART) members who can connect families with information, resources and opportunities.

title: CDC Autism Information Center
content: Provides information on autism, including symptoms, screening and diagnosis, and on treatment and therapy.  Also includes answers to frequently asked questions, information on CDC activities and links to resources for practitioners, researchers, educators and families.

title: Disability Among Children
content: Data on children with disabilities from the 1990 Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP), a nationally representative survey of the civilian non-institutionalized population.

title: DoD Special Needs Parent Toolkit
content: Provides comprehensive information and tools that are geared towards helping military families with special needs children navigate the maze of medical and special education services, community support and benefits and entitlements. The Toolkit is broken down into six colorful modules that can be easily downloaded and printed.

title: Family Village
content: Provides information on issues faced by children and youth with disabilities, including physical, intellectual and developmental disabilities, and their families.

title: Information & Resources for Girls & Young Women with an Illness or Disability
content: Information about chronic illness and disabilities from the 4girls.gov Web site.  Includes information on becoming independent, rehabilitation therapies, as well as stories shared by young people living with a disability.

title: Kid Quest Page on Disability & Health
content: Encourages kids to think about people with disabilities and some of the issues related to participation in daily activities, health and accessibility.

title: Military OneSource Special Needs Assistance
content: Provides special needs consultation, research, resources and materials intended to enhance current military services available to families with special needs.

title: National Autism Association (NAA)
content: A parent-led non-profit organization that creates and implements direct-assistance programs for families affected by autism.  Along with these services, NAA provides autism research funding, ongoing advocacy, support and education.

title: National Dissemination Center for Children with Disabilities
content: Serves as a central source of information on disabilities in infants, toddlers, children and youth; IDEA, which is the law authorizing special education; No Child Left Behind (as it relates to children with disabilities); and research-based information on effective educational practices.

title: National Institutes of Health (NIH) National Institute of Child Health & Human Development Mental Retardation & Developmental Disabilities
content: Sponsors research and training aimed at preventing mental retardation and related developmental disabilities.

title: Opening Doors - Technology & Communication Options for Children with Hearing Loss
content: Publication from the U.S. Department of Education provides information and resources for parents of children with hearing loss.

title: Resources for People Affected by Developmental Disabilities
content: Information for parents and educators on children with intellectual and other developmental disabilities, including cerebral palsy and autism spectrum disorders.

title: Supportive Health Service Needs of Children with Disabilities
content: Research paper focusing on supportive services, a subset of health-related services that are used almost exclusively by children with disabilities.

title: The Arc
content: Advocates and provides services and support for children and adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Find a chapter near you.

title: University Centers for Excellence in Developmental Disabilities Education, Research & Service (UCEDD)
content: Provide training, technical assistance, service, research and information sharing.  Includes links to technical assistance resources and a UCEDD Directory with contact information for centers in every state and territory.

title: Prioritizing Family Care for Critically Ill Children
content: Provides military families with priority space and care at respite facilities while critically ill children receive treatment at military hospitals.

title: STOMP - Specialized Training of Military Parents
content: Provides support and advice to military parents who have children with special education or health needs. STOMP is a federally funded Parent Training and Information (PTI) Center that provides information and training, connects families to other families and raises awareness of issues faced by military families of children with disabilities.

title: Shriners Hospitals for Children
content: Health care system supported by the Shriners of North America that works to improve the lives of children by providing pediatric specialty care, research and teaching programs.

title: Exceptional Parent - The Family & Professional Site for the Special Needs Community
content: Offers practical advice and emotional support to families of children and adults with disabilities and special health care needs, as well as the physicians, allied health care and educational professionals who are involved in their care and development.

title: VFW National Home for Children
content: Offers a safety net for military families when a family care plan fails, supportive services for Veterans with children who are approved for VA Vocational Rehabilitation, a chance for Veteran-related single-parent families to get a fresh start and a loving home for Veteran-related children who need it. Call the National Home Helpline at 1-800-313-4200 if you need help with supportive services and resources in your own community or if you are seeking a referral to an on-campus program.

title: ACT Today! For Military Families
content: A special campaign and outreach of ACT Today! (Autism Care and Treatment Today!) with the goal of assisting American military families with treatment programs and other special needs in order to help their children with autism realize their full potential.

title: Advancing the Health of the Family Left Behind
content: Offers advice and information for families and providers about preparing and communicating with children about deployment and reuniting.

title: Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA) Youth Centers
content: Works to promote and enhance self-worth and development in boys and girls through a variety of programs and services.  Includes information on "Youth Centers"which are formed through partnerships between BGCA and the military to provide outreach to children of service members.

title: Helping Children Cope During Deployment - Fact Sheet
content: Useful information for parent and family caregivers to help children cope during a parent's deployment.

title: Helping Kids Deal with Deployment
content: Provides guidance on how to cope with the challenges and adjustments that children and families often face during a deployment.

title: Military Children Education Coalition
content: Information to help parents and educators support children throughout the deployment cycle.

title: Operation Healthy Reunions - Reconnecting With Your Children
content: Helps parents who have been away on deployment, or gone for an extended time, reconnect with their family after they return.

title: Operation Military Kids
content: Provides information on the U.S. Army's collaborative effort with America's communities to support children and youth impacted by deployment. Includes recreational, social and educational programs, state level initiatives, camp activities, mentorship, assistance with school issues and more.

title: Returning from the War Zone - A Guide for Families of Military Members
content: Helps family members understand what to expect during the reintegration following time in a war zone and the signs of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

title: Sesame Street Deployment Video
content: A bilingual multimedia outreach program designed to support military families with children between the ages of 2 and 5 as they cope with the feelings, challenges, and concerns experienced during different phases of deployment.  Sesame Street bilingual videos, music and parent/caregiver materials are available for download at the Sesame Workshop.

title: Support for Military Children & Adolescents
content: American Academy of Pediatrics video - Military Youth Coping with Separation: When Family Members Deploy.

title: When a Parent Goes to War: Helping Your Children Cope With Their Fears
content: Discusses common reactions of children of different age groups whose parents deploy to dangerous areas.

title: Zero to Three - Young Children on the Homefront Video
content: Military families share deployment experiences and early childhood professionals offer tips for dealing with grief and loss from deployment and the challenges of reuniting.

title: National Military Family Association - Talking to Children about Deployment
content: Find useful tips for talking with and supporting your children during a loved one's deployment.

title: Grief Comfort Kit for Kids
content: A comprehensive set of resources that are informative and comforting for children and families. Includes contact information if you have questions or would like to place an order.

title: Grief Guidelines for Parents
content: Offers suggestions and advice regarding dealing with your child's grief over the loss of a loved one.

title: Hospice - Talking to Children about Death
content: Provides information for parents about talking to children about death.

title: Hospice Net's Children Section
content: Provides information for parents and other family members about children and grief and talking to children and teenagers about death.

title: Talking to Children about Death
content: Provides some general, helpful information about talking to children about death, which may be adapted to meet each family's needs.

title: Tragedy Assistance Program for Survivors (TAPS)
content: Supports and assists surviving families of those who have died in service to America through a wide variety of programs including those for grieving children and peer support programs.

title: Traumatic Grief in Military Children
content: Although posttraumatic stress reactions may occur after a deployed parent has been killed in combat, symptoms can also appear when death comes weeks or months after an initial combat injury, even if the death has been anticipated by the child or adults in the child's life.

title: War
content: Guidelines on talking to children and teens about war and responding to their fears and concerns.

title: Deployment
content: Find information to help parents and educators talk to youth about deployment, and search for recreational programs for children of Service Members and Veterans.

title: National Child Traumatic Stress Network
content: Find information on where to receive child counseling after a traumatic event.

title: Parent's Guide for Talking to their Children about War
content: Guidebook published by the National Center for Children Exposed to Violence that advises parents on how to talk with children about war and threats of terrorism.

title: Family Reading Program - United Through Reading
content: Offers deployed parents the opportunity to be video-recorded reading storybooks to their children which creates positive emotional connections and cultivates a love of reading.

title: Military Kids Connect
content:
Find information on an online community for military children (ages 6-17 years old)  			that provides access to age-appropriate resources to support them from pre-deployment, 			through a parent's or caregiver's return.
MKC offers informative activities, fun games,  			helpful videos, and interesting user surveys that can guild and reinforce understanding, 			resilience and coping skills in military children and their peers.

title: Parenting for Service Members & Veterans
content: Built by VA Mental Health Services in  partnership with DoD's National Center for  Telehealth and Technology (T2) to provide a free  online course for military and Veteran parents with information and strategies to improve their  parenting skills.

title: Military Families - Learning Communities
content: Top experts in each of the military’s service branches address issues of military culture, the impact of military deployment on children and families, and the perspectives of those serving in the U.S. Armed Services. Provides podcasts for those who care for military children and families.

title: Courage to Talk - Communicating with Your Children about Parental Injury
content: Provides tips on how to talk to children about a parent's injury and how to help them understand and cope.

title: Grieving as a Family - Finding Comfort Together
content: Provides tips, videos, children's story and a guide to help your family communicate with one another, express emotions and begin the process of moving forward in life.

title: Children of Military Service Members Resource Guide
content: Helps parents and health care providers address the mental and emotional needs of military children through topic-specific, age-related literature. Topics include community, deployment, homecoming, mental/emotional health and moving.

title: The "So Far" Guide
content: Learn how to recognize and respond to children's reaction to the deployment of a parent. Provides information to help you understand and support children throughout the deployment cycle.

title: Courage to Care Campaign
content: Provides fact sheets on health topics relevant to military life, including caring for children, depression and traumatic brain injuries.

title: Alabama Ability Loan Program
content: Provides an alternative source of financing to help individuals with disabilities, or their families, purchase adaptive equipment and services through a low-interest, extended-term loan program.

title: Alabama's Operation Grateful Heart
content: Provides programs and services to ensure that all military personnel and their families in the State of Alabama receive appropriate recognition, tangible support and neighborly care.

title: Army Family Readiness Groups (FRGs) in Alabama
content: Provides a list of Army FRGs located in Alabama, which provide a connection to unit information for spouses and other family members.

title: Military HOMEFRONT -  Alabama State Resources
content: Links to advocacy, employment, housing, health care, legal, financial and other resources available to Service Members, Veterans and their families in the State of Alabama.

title: Operation Military Kids - Alabama
content: Provides support to Army installations and geographically dispersed military youth that are affected by the global war on terrorism.

title: VA Vet Centers in Alabama
content: Provides readjustment counseling and outreach services to all Veterans who served in any combat zone and to their families for military-related issues.

title: Army Emergency Relief (AER)
content: Provides locations and contact information for AER Sections in Alabama. AER provides emergency financial assistance to soldiers, Veterans and their dependents when there is a valid need.

title: Summary of VA Programs & Services - Alabama
content: Describes the full range of VA programs, benefits and services available to Veterans and their families in Alabama.

title: Family Caregiver Alliance - Alabama State Profile
content: Provides background characteristics for Alabama related to caregiving and aging as well as information on publicly-funded caregiver support programs.

content: Helps wounded Veterans reintegrate into the workforce using career transition and job placement services.

title: Alabama Redstone Arsenal - Child & Youth Programs
content: Access information on child development centers, child care, teen programs, and youth sports.

content: Works to improve services for people with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) and their families through education and advocacy. Provides tools, information, resources and support.

content: Provides advocacy, education and awareness, as well as programs, services and support for people with intellectual and developmental disabilities and their families.

content: Learn about the relief fund created for the families of Arizona Service Members who have been injured or killed while fighting the Global War on Terror.

content: Find information on programs funded through the National Family Caregiver Support Program, Aged/Disabled Medicaid waivers and state-funded programs that either have a caregiver-specific focus, or include a family caregiving component in their service package.

content: Helps older Arizonians to be as independent as possible for as long as possible through advocacy, development and delivery of policies, programs and services which support and empower the elderly and their families.

content: Offers junior enlisted Airmen and their families at Lukes Air Force Base a place to go to receive free donated goods. All items are free for Airmen who are E-5 and below and available items range from baby supplies to military uniforms.

title: Family Caregiver Alliance - Arizona State Profile
content: Provides background characteristics for Arizona related to caregiving and aging as well as information on publicly-funded caregiver support programs.

content: Describes the full range of VA programs, benefits and services available to Veterans and their families in Arizona.

content: Find information on homework help, tutoring, school age childcare, youth clubs and more, along with guidelines and fees.

title: Marine Corps Air Station Yuma - Family Child Care
content: Here at MCAS Yuma, Family Child Care is quality, certified child care provided in homes, by trained and certified Providers, to the Air Station?s military and civilian workers.

title: Marine Corps Air Station Yuma - Counseling Support
content: Providing victim advocacy services, prevention skills training, reporting procedures for suspected abuse, incident assessment, education and rehabilitation.

title: Marine Corps Air Station Yuma - Relocation Assistance Program (RAP)
content: RAP provides helpful information for inbound/outbound personnel covering such topics such as, housing, benefits, entitlements, sponsor, housing, and special needs. Twice a month a Welcome Aboard Brief is held every third Thursday.

title: Arizona Caregiver Coalition
content: Provides support and  advocacy for family caregivers in Arizona. The  coalition was developed through the Governor's Advisory  Council on  Aging and serves a mandated role as part of the Arizona Lifespan Respite  Program.

title: Arizona Caregiver Coalition - Caregiver Resource Line
content: Accepts calls or emails 24/7 at (888) 737-7494 or crl@azcaregiver.net to connect individuals to options and resources.

title: Arizona Coalition for Military Families
content: Builds Arizona’s statewide capacity to serve and support all Service Members, Veterans, their families and communities. Part of the Community Blueprint Network.

title: The ARC of Arizona
content: Provides advocacy, education and awareness, as well as programs, services and support for people with intellectual and developmental disabilities and their families. Find a local ARC chapter in Arizona.

title: Autism Society Greater Phoenix Chapter
content: Works to improve services for people with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) and their families through education and advocacy and by providing tools, information, resources and support.

title: Arizona Child Care Services
content: Assists eligible families with child care costs, provides child care resources and referrals, and certifies small family care homes. Search for local providers in Arizona.

title: 2-1-1 Arizona
content: Call 2-1-1 for information about important health and human services in Arizona. 2-1-1 connects you to programs and services such as health care, housing, help paying utilities, transportation, mental health counseling and more.

content: Describes the full range of VA programs, benefits and services available to Veterans and their families in Arkansas.

content: Dial 2-1-1 to connect with important community services and volunteer opportunities or dial 866-489-6983.

title: The ARC of Arkansas
content: Provides support, housing, advocacy, education and leadership to people with disabilities and their families. Find a local ARC chapter in Arkansas.

title: Child Care in Arkansas
content: Provides information on child care services in Arkansas. Find licensing information, child safety support and search for local child care providers.

title: United Way of San Diego
content: Improves lives by mobilizing the caring power of the San Diego community. Focuses include stopping child abuse and neglect, promoting financial stability and independence and homeless outreach and prevention.

title: New Directions
content: Provides assistance to homeless Veterans, including residential support, counseling, substance abuse counseling, and more.

title: California Community Foundation - Iraq Afghanistan Deployment Impact Fund
content: Distributes grants to nonprofits to provide such services as counseling, child care, transportation, emergency financial assistance, support and recovery programs for the families of those wounded or killed in action.

title: Armed Services YMCA - Camp Pendleton
content: Provides support to Service Members and their families, including child care, hospital assistance, spouse support services, food services, computer training classes, health and wellness services and holiday meals.

title: San Diego Armed Services YMCA
content: Provides support services to military Service Members and their families, including child care, hospital assistance, spouse support services, food services, computer training classes, health and wellness services and holiday meals.  Check out the event calendar.

title: Twenty-Nine Palms Armed Services YMCA
content: Offers active duty and military families child care, hospital assistance, spouse support, food, computer classes, wellness, recreation and spiritual services.

title: Operation Homefront - Southern California Chapter
content: Provides emergency assistance and morale to Service Members, Veterans and their families residing in Southern California.

title: Veterans of Foreign Wars (VFW) - Department of California
content: Offers many services for the military community including free phone cards, family programs and grants for financial hardships.

title: California Family Caregiver Support Program
content: Offers information to families and caregivers in the State of California, including where to turn for support and assistance as well as services for caregivers.

title: California Department of Child Support Services
content: Provides information if you have a child support order and have been recently activated.

title: Beale Airforce Base - Airman's Attic
content: Offers junior enlisted Airmen and their families at Beale Air Force Base a place to go to receive free donated goods. All items are free for Airmen who are E-5 and below and available items range from baby supplies to military uniforms

title: FOCUS Project: Family Resiliency Training for Military Families
content: Provides resiliency training for families and children facing the challenges of combat operational stress while loved ones are deployed. Learn about available assistance,, and find programs in California, Hawaii, Mississippi, North Carolina, Virginia, Washington and Okinawa.

title: Network of Care for Seniors & People with Disabilities
content: Provides a community resource where seniors and people with disabilities, along with their caregivers and service providers, can easily access important information about issues that affect their lives.

title: Survivors of Suicide Loss
content: Supports survivors of a suicide loss and educates the community about suicide and the prevention of suicide.  Includes links to other related sites, a quarterly newsletter, volunteer opportunities and information on meetings in San Diego County.

title: Network of Care for Veterans & Service Members
content: Links critical support services to Veterans seeking jobs, housing, counseling and help within their immediate communities. The Network of Care helps individuals and family members find names and phone numbers of advocates who are in their county and can offer immediate support.

title: Operation Ready Family California
content: Provides families of the National Guard with resources to assist with deployment and transition.  We Care meetings offer opportunities to meet and network with other families and counselors.

title: Veterans Home of California (VHC)
content: Learn about Veterans Homes of California, which provide elderly and disabled Veterans with rehabilitative, residential and medical care.

title: Fisher House Comfort Homes - California
content: Provides free temporary housing for families of patients receiving medical care at major military and VA medical centers in California.

title: California Victim Compensation Program
content: Provides compensation for eligible victims of violent crime who are injured or threatened with injury. Among the crimes covered are domestic violence , child abuse, sexual and physical assault , homicide, robbery, drunk driving and vehicular manslaughter. Services include medical and dental care, mental health services, income loss, funeral expenses, rehabilitation and relocation.

title: MCCS Camp Pendleton - Children, Youth, & Teen Programs
content: Learn about services that include parent information, education, out-of-home child care and youth services for ages 6 weeks to 18 years of age (still in school). Program components include: Resource and Referral, Child Development Centers, Family Child Care, Drop In/Hourly Care, Youth Programs and School Age Care.

title: Armed Services YMCA  - Camp Pendleton
content:
Find programs and services offered by the ASYMCA for military personnel stationed at Camp Pendleton. Operation Hero is a free after school mentoring and tutoring program. Register Online 
Learn about free transportation and pre-school programs and services specifically for junior enlisted families.

title: MCCS Camp Pendleton - Counseling Services
content: Provides a variety of support services designed for active duty Service Members and their families with personal and family concerns. Assists in creating and maintaining healthy relationships and life skills through counseling, advocacy and educational services.Services include: screenings & referrals, general counseling, family & victim advocacy, and hotline information.

title: Naval Base San Diego - Childcare Resource & Referral
content: Maintains the consolidated Wait List for all six centers in Metro San Diego located on Naval Base San Diego: Naval Base Point Loma, MCRD, MCAS Miramar, Naval Medical Center and Murphy Canyon housing area and for spaces in Navy licensed Child Development Home providers (in-home care). Also find links for YMCA local resources and Military OneSource resources.

title: Naval Base San Diego - Child Development Centers
content: Offers programs for children ages 6 weeks to 5 years at Child Development Centers (CDC) throughout San Diego. Program elements include age appropriate activities, participation in the USDA food program, and monthly training requirements of staff. Find contact information for childcare centers throughout the greater San Diego area.

title: Naval Base San Diego - Youth Programs
content: The MWR Youth Programs Department operates eight housing area recreation centers and offers a wide variety of recreation programs for children ages three to seventeen. Some of these programs include open recreation, contract classes, field trips, teen programming, building rentals and special events, after school programs, day camp, and tiny tot programs.

title: Navy Region Southwest School Liaison Officers
content: Serves as a conduit between parents, educators and the command so that military-connected children experience a seamless transition during the transfer between schools.

title: Naval Base San Diego - New Parent Support
content: Provides free information & referral, nurturing parenting education and home visiting services for expectant parents and parents of children under three

title: The San Diego Regional Center
content: Serves as a focal point in the community through which people with developmental disability and their families can obtain services and be linked to other community resources.

title: California National Guard State Chaplain
content: Provides spiritual leadership and ministry that enriches the lives of California's Armed Forces, families, and local and global communities in support of the free exercise of religion in peace, disaster and war.

title: San Diego Citizen Corps Council
content: Citizens working together to make their community safer.

title: California's Troops Against Predatory Scams (TAP$)
content: Educates California's military troops on how to avoid becoming a victim of financial and investment fraud.

title: San Diego Fleet & Family Support Centers
content: Provide free workshops, services and classes to enhance the quality of life for all military members and their families, single sailors, Reservists and retirees.

title: San Diego Youth & Community Services (SDYCS)
content: Provides emergency services, safe places to live and long-term solutions for kids "on their own" by providing shelters, group homes, foster homes, community centers and transitional housing.  SDYCS is a non-profit charitable organization that since founded, has stabilized the lives of over 500,000 homeless, runaway, abused and at-risk youth in the San Diego area.

title: Resources for Military Children & Their Families
content: Assists military families when relocating to a public school in the Travis Unified School District.

title: California National Guard Financial Assistance Fund
content: Receive short term, financial assistance in the form of grants as California National Guard members and/or as a family impacted by deployment in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom or Operation Enduring Freedom.

title: Army Family Readiness Groups (FRGs) in California
content: Provides a list of Army FRGs located in California, which provide a connection to unit information for spouses and other family members.

title: California Department of Veterans Affairs (CDVA)
content: Assists California Veterans and their families in obtaining benefits, low-cost loans and medical care.

title: Operation Military Kids - California
content: Provides support to Army installations and geographically dispersed military youth who are affected by the global war on terrorism.

content: The New Parent Support Program is a support system for Marine Corps families with children ages five and under, and provides many free support services for MCRD San Diego families, including home visits and classes

title: MCRD San Diego -  Family Advocacy Program (FAP)
content: Provides education, assessments and treatment on many topics that support Marine Corps readiness through prevention and early intervention. The program addresses family violence issues through a Coordinated Community Response to promote safe family relationships and the emotional health of Marines and their families

title: 1736 Family Crisis Center
content: Find counseling services, emergency clinics, shelter for women and children, and other support services - along with 24 hr. help lines.

title: Courage to Call
content: Offers a Veteran-staffed 24/7 Helpline for Service Members and their families. Receive comprehensive information, support, resources, and/or referrals throughout the County of San Diego along with comprehensive follow up. Call the Helpline 24/7 at: (877) 698 - 7838.

title: Diversified Intervention Group (DIG)
content: Provides intervention services to men and women who suffer from alcohol and/or drug addiction, including identifying the effects on family, friends and loved ones as well as the person who is addicted. DIG will also provide post-intervention referral to a treatment program and work with the treatment program for aftercare.

title: Marine Corps Base 29 Palms - Family Life
content: Find information on programs including Marine Corps Family Team Building, the New Parent Support Program, Children, Youth & Teen Programs, and Unit, Personal & Family Readiness along with other base resources for Marine Corps families.

title: MCCS Camp Pendleton - Marine & Family Services
content: Find information about the Marine and family programs offered at Camp Pendleton including the Relocation Office, Career Center, and Program Office.

title: MCCS Camp Pendleton - Readiness & Deployment Support
content: Provides readiness education and deployment support, including pre-, during-, and post-deployment briefings and workshops. Classes include special workshops for kids and teens along with spouse specific and reunion classes.

title: Fort Irwin Survivor Outreach Services
content: Provides long-term support to families of fallen soldiers by offering assistance with any concerns or issues, services and programs and connecting families to outreach organizations both inside and outside the Department of Defense.

title: Marine Corps Community Services Camp Pendleton - Relocation Assistance
content: Find helpful information and resources whether you are just arriving at Camp Pendleton or moving to another base.

title: Marine Corps Community Services Camp Pendleton Domestic Violence Counseling
content: Assists service members and their families with personal and family concerns. If you have been the victim of spousal abuse, Victim Advocates (VA) can help advocate for rights of the victim, assist in developing safety plans and offer reporting options - or there are confidential options too. Call 760-725-9051 to speak with the duty VA, Monday-Friday 0730-1600. After hours, contact PMO at 760-763-2077 or dial 911 (on base only) and request to speak with a Victim Advocate.

title: Naval Post Graduate School - Morale, Welfare & Recreation (MWR)
content: Learn about MWR support services, locate contact information and schedules and find free movie titles and showtimes. Find links to: Child & Youth Services, the Child Development Center, Youth & Teen Center, School Liaison Services, community activities, fitness & recreation and more.

title: Naval Post Graduate School - Housing
content: Military housing is available for families and single officers at La Mesa and Fort Ord; these properties are managed by Pinnacle Housing. Find contact information and BAH rates.

title: Beale Air Force Base - Airman & Family Readiness Center
content: Find information for Air Force Personnel and family members including recreation opportunities, emergency assistance, relocation assistance, helpful links and much more.

title: Travis Air Force Base - Newcomer Information
content: Find information including a pre-arrival checklist, spouse tours of the base, in-processing information and important base links and contact numbers.

title: Travis Air Force Base - Airman & Family Readiness Center
content: Find information and links for employment resources, child care, area schools, deployment support, computer labs, relocation information, transition assistance, financial counseling, volunteer opportunities and much more.

title: Naval Base Ventura County - Fleet & Family Support Services
content: Provides services through Fleet and Family Support Centers, such as relocation assistance, new parent support, deployment services, clinical counseling services, financial management counseling, family employment services, family advocacy and the transition assistance programs.

title: Naval Base Ventura County - Child Development Centers
content: Offers full time care for children 6 weeks to 5 years of age. Children are supervised by qualified staff who receive ongoing training and provide activities that promote physical growth, motor development, thought and language development and creativity. Fees are based on total family income. Call the center for waiting list information.

title: Naval Base Ventura County - Youth Centers
content: Provides diverse, well-rounded recreation programs for children pre-school through sixth grade. The modern center features snack shops, dance, games and education classrooms. During the school months, the center has before and after school programs. Fully supervised and structured youth programs run throughout the summer. Special events, trips and games are offered during the year.

title: Naval Base Ventura County - School Liaison
content: The NBVC School Liaison Officer (SLO) is available to assist service members and their families with any K-12 school-related questions. The NBVC School Liaison Officer can be reached at (805) 989-5211 (office) or  (805) 207-3410 (cell).

title: Naval Base Ventura County - Victim Advocate Services
content: Provides support and assistance for domestic violence, sexual assault & harassment, child abuse, and other sensitive issues. Find contact information and policies on this page.

title: Fort Irwin - Morale, Welfare & Recreation (MWR)
content: Find information including soldier and family services, upcoming events, recreation options, and other support links for Service Members and families located at Fort Irwin.

title: Fort Irwin - Child, Youth & School Services
content: Fort Irwin Child, Youth & School Services (CYSS) is a network of systems and programs through which Fort Irwin provides quality child and youth development options that reduce the conflict between parental responsibilities and unit mission requirements.

title: Fort Irwin - Women, Infants & Children (WIC)
content: WIC is an educational and nutritious food check program for pregnant/nursing/postpartum women, infants, and children under the age of five. Eligibility is based on family size, income, and nutritional risk.

title: Fort Irwin - Family Advocacy Program (FAP)
content: Find emergency numbers for victims of domestic violence or to report incidents of child abuse. Provides information and education designed to support strong, self-reliant families and to enhance coping skills. FAP offers a variety of classes to meet the needs of the entire family as well as victim advocacy and the New Parent Support Program.

title: Fort Irwin - Deployment Readiness Program
content: Supports active and reserve component soldiers and their families. Guidance and assistance to Family Readiness Groups, rear detachment personnel, and families is provided. Find contact information and other base and Army resources.

title: Army Emergency Relief - Fort Irwin
content: Provides interest-free loans or grants during times of emergency. Examples are loans for eviction, vehicle repossession, emergency travel, funeral expenses, repair of Soldier's only essential vehicle, ect. Solider or Family members must visit with their Command Financial NCO prior to coming to ACS, with exception to a Red Cross Message.

title: Presidio of Monterey - Family & Morale, Welfare & Recreation
content: Find information on Army Community Services, Army Emergency Relief, Child & Youth School Services, Child Development Resources, Family Childcare, School Liaison contact information, sports & leisure options and much more.

title: Fort Hunter Liggett - Army Community Services
content: Provides education, training, awareness, outreach, information, referral and followup for Army families during deployments and when units are stateside.

title: Fort Hunter Liggett - Child, Youth & School Services

This Web site explains the steps you should take when your loved one has passed on. It also serves as a guide to federal benefits, compensation and entitlements for which you might be eligible.

title: Joint Base Anacostia - Bolling Family Housing
content: Learn about housing locations at: Bellevue Housing, Washington DC; The Landings, Washington DC; Woodbridge Run Housing, Virginia. An average wait could extend up to six months but housing may also be available at other military installations in this area. For current housing allowances and housing waiting times, call the Joint Base Housing Referral Office at 202-433-0346.

24-Hour Elder Abuse Hotline: 1-866-800-1409 1-888-206-1327 (TTY)

title: Operation Homefront
content:
Provides information and resources for Service Members, Veterans and their families in the State of Illinois. Includes financial assistance.
Illinois Office of Veterans Affairs Hotline: 1-800-437-9824.
General Information, call 312-579-9500.

title: Illinois National Guard
content: Find information on the Illinois National Guard, various units and command contact information, along with job postings and news releases.

title: Scott Air Force Base - Newcomer Information
content: Find welcome information for newcomers, both Service Members and families, to Scott AFB. Information includes contacts, directions, area schools, and introductory videos.

title: Scott Air Force Base - Family Housing Options
content: Find information on different housing options for individuals and families attached to Scott AFB. Information includes referral forms and brochures.

title: Rock Island Arsenal - Army Community Services
content: Find information including directions, upcoming events, tours for newcomers, classes such as money management,and links to important Army resources.

geographicServiceLocations.address: 1 Rock Island Arsenal Rock Island, IL 61299

title: Rock Island Arsenal - Morale, Welfare & Recreation
content: Find information including upcoming events, instillation news, barbor shop and thrift store information, and various recreation options for enlisted and officers.

title: Rock Island Arsenal - Survivor Outreach Services
content:
Find information on Survivor Outreach Services located at Rock Island Arsenal. Read the Survivor Outreach Services Brochure to learn more.
To contact your local SOS Support Coordinator: 309-782-8253.

title: Rock Island Arsenal - Family Advocacy Program (FAP)
content:
The Army Family Advocacy Program (FAP) strengthens families by providing support, education and resources. FAP is a comprehensive program to reduce and prevent family violence. Personal responsibility and family resilience are watchwords of the FAP mission.
For information on FAP programs call 309-782-3049, DSN 793-3049.  Hours are Monday - Friday 8:00 a.m. - 4:30 p.m.

title: Rock Island Arsenal - Relocation Readiness Program
content: Resources include newcomer orientations, pre-departure counseling, automated destination information, cultural liaison, youth liaisons and more. Questions regarding Relocation Programs can be addressed by calling 309-782-0816, toll free 1-877-882-0523.

title: Rock Island Arsenal - Army Emergency Relief
content: Provides emergency financial assistance to active duty soldiers, single or married, and their eligible family members; ARNG and USAR soldiers on active duty for more than 30 consecutive days and their eligible family members; soldiers retired from active duty for longevity or physical disability, and their eligible family members  .
